utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Anyway, like this one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She doesn't know about that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Anyway, so this woman says Oliver Stone once grabbed her at a party, right? He's groping her. So you get in a situation there where Oliver Stone initially said, oh, gee, I didn't realize how many people had corroborated the New York Times story, which I sense, I think, been enlarge on by the New Yorker story. But then he says, oh, at that point he thinks it's reprehensible and terrible and all that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But then you go to the story about the Amazon executive who is now on leave, this guy, Roy Price. And it's such an interesting story there because you have a woman who says she's a lesbian. A lesbian. And she says he gets in a cab and he's coming on to her and telling her all kind of awful things. And then, once she tells him that she's not only lesbian but married, he continues. And then, when she complains about it, all that happens is he doesn't appear at her parties or any event that she's involved with. And just as an aside, her dad turns out to be Philip K. Dick, who is the famous author. Why are you laughing, Mr. Gutfeld?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because I just love it when you retell an entire story.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I love it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And I know the thing that you find interesting is, she's a lesbian, and her father is name Philip Dick.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's amusing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I actually like his writing. I think science fiction is up your alley too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. To me -- do robots dream of electric sheep or something like that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, right, the man in the high castle, which is what he's starring is her daughter, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But the point is that this bad behavior is so consistent, and as we saw in the Amazon case, the higher ups don't do anything. They think they can cover it up. And we've seen this through our industry. Let me tell you, it ain't special to Hollywood.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, you're right. You're right. Can I ask a question about this -- I think when somebody says they're going to sex addiction rehab, I always feel like that's a copout because this doesn't strike me as sex addiction, this strikes me as being a really gross creep. There are people that have genuine sex addiction, like they spend hours in front of a computer and they ruin their careers.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can't function.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. They can't function. He clearly can function. He just knew he can get away with it. I think that it's not a copout. It's a way for him to pay a rich man's penance.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So you would see this actually a lot on, you know, cases that I would handle. If you have high profile defendant, especially ones that were well funded, well source, they would take their client and put them into rehab whether it was sex rehab, alcohol rehab, if it was a DUI case or sexual assault, completely two different things. He's trying to frame this as I am not a sexual predator, I am someone who has a sex addiction problem, so therefore I'm, you know, less culpable, and it's like a built-in excuse. So they're trying to do that and like persuade the judge.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did he also say when the paparazzi were in his driveway, I made a mistake?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Second chances.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sexually assaulting women is not a mistake when you do it over and over and over again, it's not a mistake.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's either a mistake or you have an addiction.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're an addicted, sexual.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's not an addiction because you're committing a crime.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Here's the addiction -- there's an addiction -- one other thing, Wade Boggs -- you remember Wade Boggs? The third baseman for the Red Sox, he said he went in for sex treatment. I never believe -- I thought what a joke this is. But in this case, men who are powerful and rich think, you know what, I can do what I want to do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's not an addiction.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what I say. But, you know what? Men like sex and here are all these starlets hanging around, right? And these guys think they can get away with it, and no one is going to call on it because as in the Weinstein situation he has so much connections, so much power, and David Boyce who was the layer that negotiated his last contract said, explicitly in the contract said, he had had these problems with, I think, there were four other women? So I mean, that's not a secret.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's an interestingly legal decision, right Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah. It's absolutely is. And we were talking about it earlier on your show. And the thing is like -- it just goes to show that these companies had prior knowledge. They knew it was a problem. They went ahead and kept him in the employment, creating an unsafe environment for those that would come in to contact with him. But they essentially were licensing criminal sexual conduct and saying that it was OK for you to do this as long as you pay us back. So they were more interested in a financial (INAUDIBLE) but had no, you know, moral qualms with that whatsoever.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did you see a class action lawsuit arising because of something like this, because of the number of women?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, we're talking about that earlier. Yeah. Because the bottom line is you can have people then join together to bring a case, like, a civil suit and, in fact, even against the company to say, look, the acted in conscience disregard of this known risk which created an unsafe environment for people. So there should be -- do you think that the jury would be very persuaded by something like that because it's pretty compelling and pretty shocking.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what struck me in reading about all of it this week was the Ronan Farrow angle. Now Ronan Farrow is the guy, the journalist for NBC. NBC doesn't take the story. He goes over to the New Yorker and the same story then become so explosive this week. So then, in people talking about why NBC executives didn't do this, they say, well, you know, some of the executives say it wasn't quite the same story. But they also say Ronan Farrow, of course, the son of Mia Farrow, had been involved with his sister making allegations against Woody Allen. And I'm wondering if people think, you know, this whole industry and all the connections, they just aren't sure. And also, NBC, of course, were the ones who withheld and then somebody leaked the tape on, guess who, President Trump and his vulgar attitude toward women.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We'll see what the weekend brings. Maybe next week we won't be talking about this as much unless there's a lot more to say. We have more to come. President Trump's recent decision on the Iran nuke deal. You're going to hear about that next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Today, President Trump announced his long-awaited decision on the disastrous Iran nuke deal arranged by his predecessor.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: The Iran deal was one of the most worst and most one-sided transactions the United States has ever entered into. What is the purpose of a deal that, at best, only delays Iran's nuclear capability for a short period of time? This, as president of the United States, is unacceptable.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He says he won't recertify the accord. But as the country isn't living up to the, quote, spirit of the deal, and had committed multiple violations.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: We will not continue down a path whose predictable conclusion is more violence, more terror, and the very real threat of Iran's nuclear breakdown. In the event we're not able to reach a solution working with congress and our allies, then the agreement will be terminated. It is under continuous review and our participation can be canceled by me as president at any time.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So if congress does not come up with satisfactory changes, he is in fact prepared to terminate it. So Dana, strong statement by the president on the discussion leading up to this in terms of what the president would do, and the involvement as well of congress.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. And when the congress passed that -- the law, they said the president, whoever the president is going to be, every 90 days have to decide if Iran is in compliance or not. When the president had done this already two times after he was sworn in, he said he did not want to do it again. He ran on his campaign saying that the deal was one of the worst that United States has ever signed on to. He was mad because -- well, that this technical compliance might be true in some cases, but that the spirit of the deal was not being lived up to, and that, in particular, talks about how Iran, for example, was sending in -- mailing in its own soil samples.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I do that too.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Exactly. So that's awfully suspicious. And then, I thought was extremely bold, and the additional step taken that I don't think people saw throughout the week until it was announced today, is that he singled out the Iranian revolutionary guard as a terrorist organization. And I think that that is actually the first time that's ever been done about another country's actual military, to call them a terrorist organization. Extremely bold. But I also note that tonight, Iranian president Hassan Rouhani said that his country will continue to stick to the nuclear deal despite U.S. President Trump's accusation that they've violated the spirit of it, and it's much stronger than Trump believes. So, I think, as Jesse and I was talking in the break, that's Jesse is right that Rouhani loves the deal because it was a better deal for Iran that it was for us.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Jesse, so, you know, this is something where Iran was like, listen, they were the beneficiary of what, at least President Trump has said and his advisors believed was an unequal bargain in terms of this deal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Completely unequal. Can we get that $3 trillion in cash back? Can we get any of that money back?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What a waste of money. Yeah, we like to claw that back, it's a terrible deal. We're all safer, even Juan, as a result of President Trump's passion today, even though he did kick it to congress which is a little risky if congress can do something in 60 days. They have a lot on their plate. I'm not so confident. We'll see what happens. But, like you've said the revolutionary guard, they're causing mayhem in Iraq. They're exporting terror through Hezbollah and through Hamas. Israel came out today extremely happy about this. The Saudis, extremely happy about this. All of our allies never thought this was a good deal. If you look at what happened with North Korea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Perfect example, we give them lots of money, we give them fuel, we've helped them build reactors, and what do they do? They waited and waited and waited and then they nuked up. And now we're under a nuclear umbrella. So that was a lesson. Trump took that lesson and is now looking at using it with the Iranians. So what do we do now? If we get out of the deal, are we safer? Everybody says, oh, no, we're not as safe if we get out. I think we're absolutely more safe. They're not even letting us inspect military sites. How is that impossible to violate? I mean, that is the key ingredient to having the deal, full, unfettered inspection. If that's not on the table and they're continuing to test their ballistic missile program, and chanting death to America, it's not a good deal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let's quote the defense secretary, Mattis, he said this deal serves the U.S. interest. How about the secretary of state, Rex Tillerson, he said that, in fact, Iran has held up their end of the deal. And then so you come to options. Number one option, congress does nothing, right? OK. And the fact Jesse said that's the most likely outcome. Second, impose economic sanctions on Iran that would kill the deal. Or third, open up new negotiations. But, of course, we're not offering anything in terms of new negotiations. We're not saying, oh, we'll give you this in exchange for that, so why would they negotiate? So we come to Rouhani, the president. Rouhani is the moderate in this situation in Iran. He wants a deal with the U.S. because he is trying to moderate a lot of the Iranian negative influence in the Middle East. It's the ayatollah who was delighted that this deal is done because the ayatollah is now saying to all the other partners, and by the way, that includes Russia, China, Britain, France, who all like this deal and don't want to decertify, and saying to them you can't trust the United States. They make deals and they break them. Do you know what this is about? This is about Donald Trump not doing ObamaCare, not being able to do tax reform, not doing a wall, and now he's saying to his base, oh, but I did this. This is terrible.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. That's like 12 segments that we have to cover right there. But I want to get Greg in, you know, and this is the president being consistent in terms of his opinion about this deal to begin with, so it's a follow-up. And today, specifically, was addressing the Iranian people directly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A moderate Iranian -- they only execute half your family. What was the central problem with the Iran deal that it was a treaty dressed up as legislation. So Obama cheated our constitution and he lied to get this thing through because he knew he couldn't get it passed. No one was going to past this terrible, terrible deal. So, this is -- the great story of this is how Trump is so far from being an autocrat, he's sending it back to Congress. He saying, let's do the right thing. I'm not going to be like President Obama and dress this thing up as something else, and tried to trick the American public. I'm going to tell you what it is. And guess what, you guys get to go back, and you guys get to work on it. Isn't that great? Why is that great? This is all about President Obama's desperate need for foreign policy legacy, so he created this horrible deal, and he shoved it through, and now we're shoving it back. And by the way, we're shoving it back in a constitutional manner.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, you know what? So congress will get this deal, Greg, and they ideally will do something to move us forward to make it safer. And to the contrary, they will not because Donald Trump just said, this is so sticky.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They're going to cut our mics.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let the other guy have it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. So coming up, jam packed, right? Trump aims to dismantle ObamaCare. Top Democrats are calling it sabotage. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: President Trump today defending his new executive order to stop payments to ensures under ObamaCare.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: You saw what we did yesterday with respect to health care. It's step-by-step-by-step. One by one, it's going to calm down and we're going to have great health care in our country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Democratic leaders Pelosi and Schumer call it a spiteful act of vast pointless sabotage levied at working families and the middle class. GOP senator Ted Cruz opposed his party last ObamaCare repeal attempt, but supports the president's move and blasts Democrats for their hypocrisy.

utterances.speaker: TED CRUZ, U.S. SENATOR
utterances.utterance: Why is it that Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer get really angry defending corporate welfare, defending billions of bailouts for insurance companies, but they're not worried about the single mom who's had her hours forcibly reduced to 29 hours a week because of ObamaCare? They're not worried about the working family whose premiums have skyrocketed, average premiums have risen over $5,000 a year under ObamaCare.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg, I can tell you this listening to Ted Cruz.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I love his voice. By the way, this isn't crony capitalism, it's crony corporatism. Unconstitutional taxpayer funded bribes to select insurance companies. It's interesting to see liberals now defending big businesses and Republicans targeting, you know, crony corporatism and evil big business. The stereotypes are now reversed. I find that quite refreshing. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, defend that because they were getting hundreds of millions of dollars in payoffs because they were losing money on the unsuccessful ObamaCare exchanges.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just say, you know, sometimes I don't know what to do. Today is Friday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I've noticed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . I just want to.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just do nothing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . to scream. Because, I mean, the idea of the whole ObamaCare -- I mean, it's so open. Reduce the number of people without insurance in America, right? Republicans.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Now the goal is to bring prices down.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. Reduce -- that was number one was reduce the number of uninsured Americans because it drives up all our cost because when those people run off to the emergency room, whatever, we end up bearing the cost anyway. But anyway, let me just say, so this is the situation at the moment where you say, you know what, we're going to help the insurance companies with insurance for low income and moderate income people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Then why do deductibles and premiums go up?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, let me just say, because they're all.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . there's a stated rising cost of health care in the country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So it didn't work?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, it did work, because it would've gone up more, Greg.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What you're going to do here is you have Blue Cross/Blue Shield. You have the American Health Insurers Association. You have pretty much everybody in the business saying this is destabilizing, and President Trump is now putting the most vulnerable in our society, in terms of health care, at risk. I just --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You mean insurance companies?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I find it loathsome. I just can't believe he did this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you find it loathsome?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I actually think it's -- it's consistent with the law. Because the House of Representatives, the Republicans challenged the -- ObamaCare's payments to these insurance companies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, power of the purse (ph).

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A federal court in February said, actually, the House and Republicans are correct, and so this is actually President Trump fulfilling the law, which again he's not an autocrat!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go, leaves and gentlemen!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Trump defending the Constitution, Kimberly Guilfoyle. It's legal.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: There you go. Very legal. Not barely legal, very legal. So here's the problem for the Democrats. This is going to be very popular with the marketplace, with the Americans, with the hardworking men and women who want to see this kind of competition is going to be a better value for them. So by the time the Democrats are done whining about it, and also pushing it through the court system, many of these changes are going to be pretty much irrevocable. So I think that it's going to be very positive move for President Trump, and also you see he was able to get the widespread support from, you know, Republicans sometimes who have sometimes been critical of him like Ted Cruz and, you know, Rand Paul. And so this, I think, was something, when I think about it in, you know, reflection and contemplate it, I say, why didn't he do it sooner?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And if Democrats are unhappy with it, why don't they come --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Exactly. Why don't they?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a good question.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- to the negotiation table --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, because they want the law.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- and start wheeling and dealing with the president?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They wanted to pass a bill.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They do! They did want to do that!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Actually, if he had done it, they --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm saying, you know, you guys, seven years Republicans have done nothing. They haven't come up with a better plan. They can't pass it. And this is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I agree with that. I agree that Republicans can't pass it. We're in agreement with that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's hard to take away the candy once it's given out.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. It's the Santa Claus principle (ph).

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Facebook Friday's" coming up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Next up, an NFL player willing to give up his job than be forced to stand for the national anthem.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: My God, what a lunatic!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm going to say it (ph). Just when you thought the NFL protests were dying down, one wide receiver may take his protest one step further. Tennessee Titans player Rishard Matthews tweets he will step away from the league, in other words quit, if it implemented a new rule requiring players to stand for the national anthem. So the owners are expected to discuss this issue next week. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If he wants to give up the job he loves for his principles, that's fine. Let him do it. It doesn't matter to me. You know, I don't know how great of an asset he is to the team. I don't really -- I don't really know how many balls he's caught this season so far. But I don't think his teammates would want him to bail out for something like that. I mean, this is still a team sport. And if you're going to leave on something as small as your right to take a knee, I bet the rest of the team might be a little upset about it. Maybe not the second-string wide receiver who will come up and take your spot. Probably everybody else.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Kimberly, the NFL said that they will not mandate that the players stand.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, I mean, really, what is this guy trying to do? You know, just invite, you know, bad luck into his life and to his front doorstep? I mean, it's just ridiculous, you know? He's got a great opportunity to play a game that, you know, people love and do something to be able to provide for his family. It's just not smart. Just when the baseball players, like when the whole strike -- that didn't work out well for them. And ultimately, he's hurting the other players on his team, too, by doing that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So now we have a situation, Dana, where there's a sheriff who says he's boycotting Ford, because Ford put out a statement saying that players have the right to express their, you know, upset with the way that cops deal with black people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Isn't it -- isn't it great in America that you can have all this freedom to say or do whatever you want?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So they can boycott. He can say -- they can say what they want to about the players. I mean, that's actually what it's about. I really thought that Condoleezza Rice earlier this week answered it very well. And I think if these players heard her, they might change their mind. And she said that you stand in unison and respect, not because the nation is perfect but because it is imperfect. And that there's still work to do. And he also is going to be giving $75,000 to local communities to deal with this issue. So he's got a great platform. I hope that he wouldn't quit and maybe decide to stand to try to make the country better. And also to put his money where his mouth is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what I thought was impressive about Condoleezza Rice's statement? And of course, the reason I thought it was impressive is because I agree with her. Is that what she said, as I heard it, was if you are trying to persuade other people, you don't allow them to divert the conversation. And what has happened is now you have, unfortunately, to my mind, it's become a black/white issue -- and you can see this in the polling -- where people say, "Oh, this is about the flag, the anthem, or the military," and the players say, "No, my mom was in the military. My dad is in the military, et cetera. It has nothing to do with that. This is about police brutality."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I wonder who said that about three times in the last month, that if only the protest was made clear, people would understand it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But that's the problem. It wasn't clear. Look, years from now, we're going to look back at this and see how irrational this country became due to identity politics, where identity politics infects. It becomes a game of chicken between sides. Because one side gets offended by the other, and then it goes -- it just keeps going. You're seeing this on campuses now, where people are shouting down people. It's a game of chicken. So let's take it to the ultimate. Why don't we just speed to the end? I have an idea for the biggest football game ever that will get the biggest game ever. Settle it once and for all. Kneelers versus the standers. You get the best kneelers, you get the best standers, and they play the game. You turn the game into an actual political battle. Settle it once and for all.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wow. The standers are going to win, especially if Kaepernick is the quarterback for the kneelers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why not kneelers versus standers?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Let me put a bet on that game.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: One person could put this together. Where is Don King?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don King, yes. Bob Aaron (ph). They'll put it together. But you know, so apparently, last night in Charlotte, you had people outside the stadium taking a knee during the anthem. Again, expressed their concern about this issue. Now, your point to me is, "Oh, gee, this really is a waste of time." I don't think it's a waste of time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I never said that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You don't think it's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I just said that an -- a poor protest is when an overwhelming majority do not understand it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But there are a lot --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But do you think it's -- do you think that this has become, like, team sport politics, where they intentionally are not understanding, because they don't want to deal with the racial issue?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no. I will never respect a man who has -- wears socks with (UNINTELLIGIBLE) the cops.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That seems like such a distraction.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He wore them on purpose! Not as a distraction, but to get attention. That was part of his protest.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's the biggest issue at the table?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: As cops are being targeted and executed? Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And by the way, you know, play the game. Be respectful. You're getting paid a lot of money to be there at the stadium. And if you feel so inclined you would like to express yourself and engage in this type of, you know, social injustice protest, then why don't you do it on your free time and actually do that and show that you're personally invested, instead of while you're being paid to do something?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the cameras didn't even show the national anthem at last night's football game, because they know it's hurting the bottom line.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are we done with this?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you know, in fact, the NFL may --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Please!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I mean, come on!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Greg, can you do the job that you're paid to do and participate in this segment?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is why we only do one question on "Facebook Friday."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're right. I want to do "Facebook Friday." OK, don't move. Don't move a bone. "Facebook Friday" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A little theme music from "Friday the 13th," Facebook addition.

utterances.speaker: OK, Maryellen F. -- what a great name -- asks this question, Kimberly
utterances.utterance: "If you could come back, on the next life, who would you like to be?"

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You're such a hater. I just said for the break, I'm like, "Hey, don't come to me first." And you're "Hey, Kimberly." OK, I've got an answer for you. Margaret Thatcher.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Interesting.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Very good choice, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You should've said Juan Williams so I would have come to you second.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So I'd be silent, screaming inside --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You've got it!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- my new body.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You've got it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Claw my way out of my own body.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Confused.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, if you can come back --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I really appreciate that you -- you have a sense of what I go through every day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Counseling session.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Next life, Juan. What would you like to come back?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So you can't come back as Jesus, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. You can if you want, but that's -- you're shooting pretty high there. You think you can do a better job?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You can't get a job, because if you kneel during the anthem, they wouldn't say you were praying. Right? So you would be out of a job. So what do you think? So who's having the most fun? Tom Brady, you once told me Tom Brady is married to a beautiful woman, makes a lot of money. I think he's the most popular football player?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't know. We went to the same high school. That's all I know.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, his diet is --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You're not going to like that diet.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What do you mean? As long as they have ice cream, I'm OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, he's not. No.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I don't think they even have that. I couldn't live in the same house as him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'd come back as my mother.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's interesting and strange. Because that means you would sleep with your father!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, man!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Eww!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Do you see what I -- do you see what goes on here?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm just pointing out the obvious! That is why I'm here on the show, to point out the obvious!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That is so -- oh!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Say David Schwimmer.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm going to go with David Schwimmer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Then somebody goes, "You look like Jesse Watters."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think he's had too much cold medicine.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's using my name to get into places.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's awesome, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's a good one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm going to come back as Jasper. That's life.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Spoiled dog.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because you'd be his owner?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is -- that is pretty strange. I would come back as planet Earth.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's not --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And you'd all be all over me.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No. That is not a person.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, but --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You violated that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is a collection of people. I want to come back as planet earth. I deserve it. I've been through a lot.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This answers Kimberly's question. Why is Greg so gaseous?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Because he's had so many people inside his body?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He's earth, he's earth.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A lot of flora.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is a great question.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What is going on?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'll start with you, Dana. From Krissy K., "What was your first cartoon lunch box as a kid?"

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Peanuts. Like the --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Don't swear.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Charlie the Brown [SIC] comic strip thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yellow. It had a red handle.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Also, there was Holly Hobby, but I don't know which was first.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Interesting. Very good. It tells you what era you were in. What was yours?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Transformers, He-man, something like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes. The lunch box smell, I just hated, Jess. I just hated it smell of it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I loved my thermos.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What kind did you have? Why didn't you just, like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I had the brown bag with the grease spot.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Eww.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it was, like, a New York Mets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sports.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry to hear that, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me tell you, I've got a lot to be sorry about on the baseball front.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. K.G.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Totally. So mine was Pele.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Pele.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I loved my Pele lunch box. Am I dating myself right now?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. But I loved it. I loved to play soccer and I played on an all-boys team. It was perfect for me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You were a trailblazer.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: My lunch box with "The Firing Line." Interesting. Anyway.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You mean Bill Buckley?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I bet you didn't know "The Firing Line" had a lunch box?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Interesting.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You were a special premium subscriber?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Came with a pipe.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think you're making this up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kind of a similar question. I'll go to you, Jessie. What toy from your childhood do you remember fondly or do you still have? That's interesting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, my mother threw out my Nintendo. I'm still bummed out about that. She also threw out all of my "Star Wars" toys, you know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- those things that you put together. And those are probably a lot of money.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So not happy about that either.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: When did you throw them out? Like last week?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What about you, Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, let's see. So -- no. You know, Nintelevision? It's like a Nintendo, but it was like in television? Anyway, but no, I wasn't upset about it. I used to play with my brother, and then my dad made us give it away to some other children that had lost their mom. We gave it to them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Aww.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That was nice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: But that was a good memory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Toy from your childhood?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, I was just thinking. Silly Putty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Love that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Isn't that cool?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Love that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I really did. And the funny thing is I don't even know if it's even around anymore.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It think it still is. It still is. Taste weird. Not as delicious as Play-Doh. Kids, don't eat Play-Doh. You'll end up like me. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I had a "Sesame Street" -- it was like a house, and you could open it up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then you could put the little figurines inside, all the different --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You used to run around in there?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I did.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, she did. Favorite toy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Glass houses, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: My favorite toy, a stick. Loved a nice stick.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nice stick.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A nice stick, yes. And you know --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Not even a boomerang?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. A stick is the original boomerang. It really is. Throw a stick, it doesn't come back, who cares? You find another stick. You don't need the stick to come back. There are sticks everywhere.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No carbon footprint.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You must have had a great childhood.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I did. I had a wonderful childhood. Lots of sticks. All right. "What Disney villain would you like to be?" Juan. From Sherri S.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Disney villains?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I have to think here. So who's a Disney villain?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Say "Snow White."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Cruella de Ville.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Cruella de Ville, I think she's pretty strong.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Snow White was not a villain.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was a joke.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because we keep talking about race.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Do we have to be a villain?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes -- no, well, that's the question. I can't change the question. They're wrapping me up. It's 5:51.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We'll answer it later.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Sorry, kids. "One More Thing" up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, it's my turn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Time for "One More Thing." I thought it was Kimberly! Because Kimberly is first. So Kimberly, sorry.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Thank you, my love. All right. Well, it's time to feast your eyes on this.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: "Kimberly's Food Court."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yay!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes, indeed. And let me tell you something. This mamacita loves some noodles. And I'm super excited, because a very famous New York restaurant has opened back up again. New York City noodle fans are freaking out about this, including me, return of the legendary Szechuan restaurant Hwa Yuan. OK? Down on Broadway. And they originally closed down in 1992, but they were really famous and known for their noodles. The queen loved the place, Bacall, Mayor Koch.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why does America care?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They care because it's an American success story, a family that escaped communist China and opened this restaurant to live the American dream.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So good.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Thanks to Jimmy Tang is here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Delicious.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And his father opened it up, and so it's super exciting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Really good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There they are. There's the picture.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Jimmy and his father. Was very excited, who's the chef here. And also your grandfather that started, Shorty Tang. And this is so good. This is Chinese pizza.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dude, you just got a half a million dollars of free advertising.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. OK, now that I know what I'm doing, I will tell you about this. Do any of you play Pokemon? Did you ever hear of that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. So if your Pokemon was mean to you during the 2016 investigation, guess what? Apparently, there's an investigative report out today that Russia even tried to get inside the Pokemon to be mean to you. I don't know exactly how this works, but they were very savvy, the Russians, on some of these things. So if you were upset and you think fellow Americans were doing this to you, chances are it was probably the Russians, of course. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This was not my One More Thing, but my mom just texted me and she's demanding an on-air apology.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Uh-oh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Apparently, she did not throw away all my toys when I was a younger boys. She offered them to me, and then I threw them away. I don't know. That could be fake news.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: From your mom?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Could be fake news.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, my mom wants to meet your mom.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's what she -- that's what she was offended by?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, we had that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Among other things. Anyway, I just want to plug "Watters' World," 8 p.m. Saturday night. We have a great lineup. We have Tomi Lauren. We have Jesse Watters, obviously. Sebastian Gorka, and Curt Schilling, probably the most conservative lineup I've ever had.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's going to be a great show and hopefully you guys will all --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is fair and balanced.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I balance it out.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He listed himself.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Will you be doing mom texts on that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: [IMITATING SEBASTIAN GORKA] Sebastian Gorka. Sebastian Gorka.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's scary.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So my show tomorrow, it's going to be amazing. I've got the great writer Walter Kern. I've got Emily Capagno (ph). I've got Kat Timpf, Tyrus. And Tippi Hedron, the star of "The Birds" is going to coming on and talk about her experience in Hollywood working for Alfred Hitchcock. And you don't want to miss that. Now it's time for --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Greg's Evil News.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So today it's Friday the 13th. Are you aware that today is the last ever Flight 666 to Hell?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The Nordic Air has flown passengers from Copenhagen to Helsinki, Finland on Friday the 13th since 2006, and they've decided to retire the flight number, which is 666.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that sounds fair.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So you cannot fly to Hell on the triple six.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's kind of interesting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That sure beats, you know, "I'm starting up a restaurant."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How about Pokemon? OK, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. There's no crying in baseball, but man, I was screaming after midnight last night, because --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- my Nationals were defeated and eliminated from the playoffs. One particular play in particular is causing a storm to rise in my soul. Here you see the play, but notice, the Cubs patter hits the mask of the catcher's mask with his bat. That's against the rules!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Two runs scored on the play. The umpiring crew decided not to enforce the blanking rule. Now, I don't -- it's not that I have any strong feelings about this --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Watch your mouth.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wait, what?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- but I'm going to tell you something. That cost us the game, you idiot!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What is wrong with Juan? Juan is not that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What is right with Juan? What is right with Juan?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow. That's amazing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, these people, they don't follow the rules!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now you care about the rules?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Now you do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Mr. Sanctuary City. Maybe that's a sanctuary on base.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, look --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, you guys. Bret Baier is going to love this lead-in. All right. "Special Report" is up next. END Content and Programming Copyright 2017 Fox News Network, LLC.
